Problem Statement:
A partially elliptically polarized beam of light, propagating in the $z$ direction, passes through a perfect linear polarization analyser. When the tranemission axis of the analyzer is along the $x$ direction, the transmitted intensity is maximum and has the value $1.5 I_{0}$. When the transmission axis is along the $y$ direction, the transmitted intensity is minimum and has the value $I_{0}$.

What is the intensity when the transmission axis makes angle $\theta$ with the $x$-axis?
Solution:
Let the intensity of the unpolarized light after passing through the analyzer be $I_{u}$. This will remain constant whatever angle the transmission axis makes with the $x$-axis. Let the intensities of the $x$ and $y$ components of the elliptically polarized light be $I_{e x}$ and $I_{e y}$ respectively. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{x}=1.5 I_{0}=I_{u}+I_{\mathrm{ex}}, \\
&I_{y}=1.0 I_{0}=I_{u}+I_{\mathrm{ey}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Fig. $2.69$

An elliptical vibration can be considered as made up of two mutually perpendicular linear ones $90^{\circ}$ out of phase as shown in Fig. 2.69. Its electric field vector can be represented by

$$
\mathbf{E}_{\theta}=\mathbf{E}_{x} \cos \theta+\mathbf{E}_{y} \sin \theta .
$$

The intensity of the polarized component $I_{e}$ is then $I_{e} \sim\left|\mathbb{E}_{0}\right|^{2}$, or

$$
I_{e}=I_{e x} \cos ^{2} \theta+I_{e y} \sin ^{2} \theta .
$$

Hence, writing $I_{u}=I_{u} \cos ^{2} \theta+I_{u} \sin ^{2} \theta$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
I(\theta) &=I_{\mathrm{e}}+I_{\mathrm{u}}=\left(I_{\mathrm{ex}}+I_{\mathrm{u}}\right) \cos ^{2} \theta+\left(I_{\mathrm{ey}}+I_{\mathrm{u}}\right) \sin ^{2} \theta \\
&=1.5 I_{0} \cos ^{2} \theta+I_{0} \sin ^{2} \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus $I(\theta)$ does not depend on what fraction of the light is unpolarised.

Problem Statement: A double-slit interference is produced by plane parallel light of wavelength $\lambda$ passing through two slits of unequal widths, say $w_{1}=20 \lambda$ and $w_{\Omega}=40 \lambda$, their centers being $1000 \lambda$ apart. If the observation is made on a screen very far away from the slits, i.e., at a distance $L \gg 1000 \lambda$, determine the separation $\delta x$ between adjacent maxima.
Solution:
As $w_{2}=2 w_{1}, L>w_{1}, w_{2}$, we may take the amplitudes of the electric field vectors produced by the slits $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ individually on the screen to be $E$ and $2 E$ respectively. Since $I \propto E^{2}$, the corresponding intensities are $I_{1}=I_{0}$, say, $I_{2}=4 I_{0}$. For double-slit interference the resultant amplitude is given by the vector sum of $E_{1}$ and $E_{2}$ making an angle $\delta$ equal to the phase difference. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=I_{1}+I_{2}+2 \sqrt{I_{1} I_{2}} \cos \delta \\
&=I_{0}+4 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2 \pi d \sin \theta / \lambda)=5 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2000 \pi \sin \theta),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $d$ is the separation of the centres of the slits, being equal to $1000 \lambda$, $\sin \theta \approx \frac{x}{L}, x$ being the distance on the screen from the centre of the interference pattern. As $L>x, \sin \theta \simeq \theta$ and adjacent maxima occur when $2000 \pi \delta \theta=2 \pi$, or $\delta \theta=\frac{1}{1000}$, giving

$$
\delta x=L \delta \theta=\frac{L}{1000} .
$$

Problem Statement: A parabolic mirror of small relative aperture ($10 \mathrm{~cm}$ dia, $500 \mathrm{~cm}$ focal length) is used to photograph stars. Roughly what is the diameter of the image "blob" for a star on axis for visible light (take $\lambda=5000 \AA$)?
Solution:
For photographing stars, the dominant limitation of resolution is the Fraunhofer diffraction by the aperture of the telescope. The diameter of the image "blob" (the Airy disk) of a star on axis is

$$
d=\frac{1.22 \lambda f}{D} .
$$

With $D=10 \mathrm{~cm}, f=500 \mathrm{~cm}$ and $\lambda=5000 \AA$ we have

$$
d=0.3 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~cm} .
$$

For a atar off axis, the ray makes an angle $\theta$ with the axis of the telescope. So the effective diameter of the aperture reduces to $D \cos \theta$, and the diameter of the Airy disk becomes

$$
d^{\prime}=\frac{1.22 \lambda f}{D \cos \theta} .
$$

Problem Statement: An opaque sheet has a hole in it of $0.5 \mathrm{~mm}$ radius. If plane waves of light $(\lambda=5000 \AA)$ fall on the sheet, find the maximum distance from this sheet at which a screen must be placed so that the light will be focused to a bright spot.
Solution:
The maximum distance $r$ of the screen from the hole for which the light will be focused to a bright spot is that for which the area of the hole corresponds to the first Fresnel zone only, and is given by

$$
\rho_{1}^{2}=\lambda r,
$$

where $\rho$ is the radius of the hole. Hence

$$
r=\frac{\rho_{1}^{2}}{\lambda}=\frac{0.5^{2}}{5000 \times 10^{-7}}=500 \mathrm{~mm} .
$$

Without the opaque screen, the number of the Fresnel zones will approach infinity. The total amplitude is then

hence

$$
\begin{aligned}

&=\frac{A_{1}}{2}+\left(\frac{A_{1}}{2}-A_{2}+\frac{A_{3}}{2}\right)+\left(\frac{A_{3}}{2}-A_{4}+\frac{A_{5}}{2}\right)+\ldots \\
& \approx \frac{A_{1}}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
I^{\prime} \sim A_{1}^{2} / 4 \text {, i.e., } I^{\prime}=I_{1} / 4
$$

Thus the intensity is now $1 / 4$ that before the opaque sheet is removed.

Problem Statement:
Monochromatic parallel light impinges normally on an opaque screen with a circular hole of radius $r$ and is detected on the axis a distance $L$ from the hole. The intensity is observed to oscillate as $r$ is increased from 0 to $\infty$.

Find the radius $r_{\mathrm{a}}$ of the hole for the first maximum.
Solution:
For parallel incident light and a point on the axis distance $L$ from the hole, the radii of the Fresnel zones are given by

$$
r_{k}=\sqrt{k \lambda L}, \quad(k=1,2,3, \ldots) .
$$

For the first maximum, $k=1, r_{\mathrm{a}}=r_{1}=\sqrt{\lambda L}$.

Problem Statement:
Assume a visible photon of $3 \mathrm{eV}$ energy is absorbed in one of the cones (light sensors) in your eye and stimulates an action potential that produces a $0.07$ volt potential on an optic nerve of $10^{-9} \mathrm{~F}$ capacitance.

Calculate the energy of the action potential.
Solution: $Q=V C=0.07 \times 10^{-9}=7 \times 10^{-11}$ Coulomb.$E=\frac{Q V}{2}=\frac{1}{2} \times 7 \times 10^{-11} \times 0.07=2.5 \times 10^{-12}$ joule.

Problem Statement: Find the angular separation in seconds of arc of the closest two stars resolvable by the following reflecting telescope: $8 \mathrm{~cm}$ objective, $1.5$ meter focal length, $80$X eyepiece. Assume a wavelength of $6000 \AA$. ($1 \AA=10^{-8}$ cm).
Solution:
The angular resolving power of the telescope is

$$
\Delta \theta_{1}=1.22 \frac{\lambda}{D}=1.22 \times \frac{6000 \times 10^{-8}}{8} \approx 2^{\prime \prime} .
$$

The resolving power of the human eye is about 1 minute of arc. Using an eyepiece of magnification $80 \mathrm{X}$, the eye's resolving power is $\Delta \theta_{2}=1^{\prime} / 80<$ $2^{\prime \prime}$. Therefore, the resolvable angular separation of stars using the telescope is $\Delta \theta=\max \left(\Delta \theta_{1}, \Delta \theta_{2}\right)=2^{\prime \prime}$.

Solution:
An object infinite distance away finds its image on the back focal plane of the converging lens, i.e., at $20-15=5 \mathrm{~cm}$ behind the diverging lens. The Gaussian lens formula

$$

$$
m=\frac{h}{h^{\prime}}=\frac{10}{5}=2 .
$$

Hence the size of the final image is

Problem Statement: Solar energy at the rate $800 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$ strikes a flat solar panel for water heating. If the panel has absorptance $=0.96$ for all wavelengths and the sides are perfect insulators, calculate the maximum temperature of the water.
Solution:
The Stefan-Boltzmann law gives, under equilibrium,

$$
\alpha \phi=\sigma T^{4}
$$

where $\sigma=5.67 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{~K}^{4}$ is Stefan's constant, $\phi$ is the solar energy flux density, and $\alpha$ is the absorptance of the panel. With

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma &=5.67 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{~K}^{4}, \\
\alpha &=0.96, \\
\phi &=800 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}^{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

we obtain $T=341 \mathrm{~K}$ for the maximum temperature of the water. As

$$
T \propto \alpha^{1 / 4},
$$

when $\alpha^{\prime}=\alpha / 2$, we have

$$
T^{\prime}=(1 / 2)^{1 / 4} \mathrm{~T}=286 \mathrm{~K} .
$$

Thus if the absorptance dropped by $1 / 2$, the maximum temperature would be $286 \mathrm{~K}$.

Problem Statement: A double-slit interference is produced by plane parallel light of wavelength $\lambda$ passing through two slits of unequal widths, say $w_{1}=20 \lambda$ and $w_{\Omega}=40 \lambda$, their centers being $1000 \lambda$ apart. If the observation is made on a screen very far away from the slits, i.e., at a distance $L \gg 1000 \lambda$, determine an analytic expression for the intensity on the screen as a function of $x$ when $x=0$ is at the exact center of the pattern.
Solution:
As $w_{2}=2 w_{1}, L>w_{1}, w_{2}$, we may take the amplitudes of the electric field vectors produced by the slits $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ individually on the screen to be $E$ and $2 E$ respectively. Since $I \propto E^{2}$, the corresponding intensities are $I_{1}=I_{0}$, say, $I_{2}=4 I_{0}$. For double-slit interference the resultant amplitude is given by the vector sum of $E_{1}$ and $E_{2}$ making an angle $\delta$ equal to the phase difference. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=I_{1}+I_{2}+2 \sqrt{I_{1} I_{2}} \cos \delta \\
&=I_{0}+4 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2 \pi d \sin \theta / \lambda)=5 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2000 \pi \sin \theta),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $d$ is the separation of the centres of the slits, being equal to $1000 \lambda$, $\sin \theta \approx \frac{x}{L}, x$ being the distance on the screen from the centre of the interference pattern. As $L>x, \sin \theta \simeq \theta$ and adjacent maxima occur when $2000 \pi \delta \theta=2 \pi$, or $\delta \theta=\frac{1}{1000}$, giving

$$
\delta x=L \delta \theta=\frac{L}{1000} .
$$The diffraction intensity distribution due to a slit of width $w$ is given by $\sim\left(\frac{\sin \beta}{\beta}\right)^{2}$, where $\beta=\frac{\pi w}{\lambda} \sin \theta$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{1}=I_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{1} / \beta_{1}\right)^{2}, \quad \text { where } \beta_{1}=\pi w_{1} \sin \theta / \lambda=20 \pi \sin \theta, \\
&I_{2}=4 I_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{2} / \beta_{2}\right)^{2}, \quad \text { where } \beta_{2}=\pi w_{2} \sin \theta / \lambda=40 \pi \sin \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

The first zeros occur at angular distances from the centre of $\theta_{1}$ and $\theta_{2}$ given by

$$
20 \pi \sin \theta_{1} \simeq 20 \pi \theta_{1}=\pi \text {, or } \theta_{1}=\frac{1}{20} \text {, and } \theta_{2}=\frac{1}{40} \text {. }
$$

Hence the angular widths of the central maxima are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \theta_{1}=2 \theta_{1} &=\frac{1}{10}, \\
\Delta \theta_{2} &=\frac{1}{20} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The corresponding widths are then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\Delta x_{1}=L \theta_{1}=L / 10, \\
&\Delta x_{2}=L \theta_{2}=L / 20 .
\end{aligned}
$$The width of the overlap of these central maxima is $L / 20$, and the number of fringes is $(\mathrm{L} / 20) /(\mathrm{L} / 1000)=50$.The intensity maximum and minimum in the center of the pattern are given by $\cos \delta=1$ and $\cos \delta=-1$ respectively. Hence we have the ratio

$$
\frac{I_{\max }}{I_{\min }}=\frac{9 I_{0}}{I_{0}}=9 .
$$Taking diffraction effect into account gives the fields produced by $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ respectively as

$$
\begin{aligned}
&E_{1}=E_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{1} / \beta_{1}\right), \\
&E_{2}=2 E_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{2} / \beta_{2}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $E_{0}$ is a constant.

With $\beta_{2}=2 \beta_{1}$, we have

$$
E=\left|\mathbb{E}_{1}+\mathbb{E}_{2}\right|=E_{0} \frac{\sin \beta_{1}}{\beta_{1}}(5+4 \cos \delta)^{\frac{1}{2}}
$$

The intensity is therefore

$$
I(x)=I_{0}\left(\frac{\sin \frac{20 \pi x}{L}}{\frac{20 \pi x}{L}}\right)^{2}\left(5+4 \cos \frac{2000 \pi x}{L}\right)
$$

Problem Statement: A Michelson interferometer is adjusted to give a fringe pattern of concentric circles when illuminated by an extended source of light of $\lambda = 5000 \AA$. How far must the movable arm be displaced for $1000$ fringes to emerge from the center of the bullseye?
Solution:
Concentric circles, called fringes of equal inclination, are obtained when the two reflecting mirrors are exactly mutually perpendicular. The optical path length difference $\Delta$ between the two arms is given by

$$
\Delta=2 n d \cos \theta=2 n\left(l_{1}-l_{2}\right) \cos \theta,
$$

where $n$ is the index of refraction of the medium (for air, $n=1$ ), $d=l_{1}-l_{2}$ is the path length difference (OPD) between the arms of lengths $l_{1}$ and $l_{2}$, $\theta$ is the angle of incidence of light at the mirrors.

(1) For 1000 fringes to emerge from the center of the bullseye, the OPD $\Delta$ must undergo a change of $1000 \lambda$. Thus $2 d=1000 \lambda$, or $d=500 \lambda=0.25$ $\mathrm{mm}$, i.e., the movable arm is displaced by $0.25 \mathrm{~mm}$.
(2) If the center is bright, we have

$$
2 d=m \lambda,
$$

where $m$ is an integer.

For the first dark ring, we have

$$
2 d \cos \theta=\left(m-\frac{1}{2}\right) \lambda .
$$

Subtracting yields

$$
2 d(1-\cos \theta)=\frac{\lambda}{2} .
$$

For small $\theta, \cos \theta \approx 1-\frac{\theta^{2}}{2}$, hence

$$
\theta \approx \sqrt{\lambda / 2 d} \operatorname{rad} .
$$

For $d=0.25 \mathrm{~mm}$, we obtain $\theta=0.032 \mathrm{rad}=1.8^{\circ}$.

Problem Statement:
A point source $S$ located at the origin of a coordinate system emits a spherical sinusoidal wave in which the electric field $E_{1}$ is given by $E_{1}=$ $A\left(\frac{D}{r}\right) \cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi r}{\lambda}\right)$, where $r$ is the distance from $S$. \begin{aligned}
E &=E_{1}+E_{2}=A\left[\frac{D}{r} \cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi r}{\lambda}\right)+\cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi x}{\lambda}\right)\right] \\
& \approx A\left[\cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi r}{\lambda}\right)+\cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi x}{\lambda}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have used the approximation $r \approx D$.

For $y<D$, we have

$$
r=\left(D^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} \approx D\left(1+\frac{y^{2}}{2 D^{2}}\right)
$$

and thus

Hence

$$

E &=A\left[\cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi D\left(1+\frac{y^{2}}{2 D^{2}}\right)}{\lambda}\right)+\cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi D}{\lambda}\right)\right] \\
&=2 A \cos \frac{\pi y^{2}}{D \lambda} \cdot \cos \left(\omega t-\frac{2 \pi D\left(1+\frac{y^{2}}{4 D^{2}}\right)}{\lambda}\right) .

$$

I \propto E^{2} \propto \cos ^{2} \frac{\pi y^{2}}{D \lambda} .

$$

As the distance from the centre increases, the fringes become closer. This is similar to Fresnel's zone plate.

Problem Statement:
The radius of curvature of the convex surface of a plano-convex lens is $30 \mathrm{~cm}$. The lens is placed with its convex side down on a plane glass plate, and illuminated from above with red light of wavelength $650 \mathrm{~nm}$ (see the figure).

Find the diameter of the third bright ring in the interference pattern.
Solution:
The radii of the bright Newton's rings are given by the following formula,

$$
r_{j}=\sqrt{(2 j+1) \frac{\lambda}{2} R} \quad(j=0,1,2, \ldots) \text {. }
$$

For the third bright ring, $j=2$, and the radius is

$$
r=\sqrt{(4+1) \times \frac{650 \times 10^{-7}}{2} \times 30}=0.7 \mathrm{~mm}
$$

i.e., the diameter is

$$
d=2 r=1.4 \mathrm{~mm} .
$$

Problem Statement:
A self-luminous object of height $h$ is $40 \mathrm{~cm}$ to the left of a converging lens with a focal length of $10 \mathrm{~cm}$. A second converging lens with a focal length of $20 \mathrm{~cm}$ is $30 \mathrm{~cm}$ to the right of the first lens.

Calculate the ratio of the height of the final image to the height $h$ of the object.
Solution:
From $\frac{1}{f_{1}}=\frac{1}{u_{1}}+\frac{1}{v_{1}}$, where $f_{1}=10 \mathrm{~cm}, u_{1}=40 \mathrm{~cm}$, we obtain $v_{1}=13 \frac{1}{3} \mathrm{~cm}$.

From $\frac{1}{f_{2}}=\frac{1}{u_{2}}+\frac{1}{v_{2}}$, where $f_{2}=20 \mathrm{~cm}, u_{2}=\left(30-\frac{10}{3}\right) \mathrm{cm}$, we obtain $v_{2}=-100 \mathrm{~cm}$, i.e., the final image is $100 \mathrm{~cm}$ to the left of the second lens.The ratio of the final image height to the height $h$ of the object can be calculated from

$$
m=m_{2} \times m_{1}=\left(\frac{v_{2}}{u_{2}}\right)\left(\frac{v_{1}}{u_{1}}\right)=-2 .
$$

The minus sign signifies an inverted image.

Problem Statement:
A plane wave of wavelength $\lambda$ is incident on a system having 3 slits of width a separated by distances $d$. The middle slit is covered by a filter which introduces a $180^{\circ}$ phase change.

Calculate the angle $\theta$ for the first interference minimum.
Solution:
By the Huygens-Fresnel principle, the amplitude at a point on the screen is given by (for Fraunhofer diffraction)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi=& \frac{A_{0}}{a} e^{-i w t}\left[\int_{0}^{a} e^{i 2 \rho x} d x\right.\\
&\left.+\int_{d}^{d+a} e^{i(2 \rho x+\pi)} d x+\int_{2 d}^{2 d+a} e^{i 2 \rho x} d x\right] \\
=& A_{0} e^{-i w t} e^{i \rho a} \frac{\sin (\rho a)}{\rho a}\left(1-e^{i 2 \rho d}+e^{i 4 \rho d}\right) e^{i 2 \rho d} \\
=& A_{0} e^{i(\beta+4 \gamma-w t)} \frac{\sin \beta}{\beta} \frac{\cos (3 \gamma)}{\cos \gamma},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\rho=\frac{\pi}{\lambda} \sin \theta, \beta=\rho a, \gamma=\rho d$. Thus

$$
I \sim\left(\frac{\sin \beta}{\beta}\right)^{2}\left[\frac{\cos (3 \gamma)}{\cos \gamma}\right]^{2} .
$$

The first diffraction minimum occurs at

$$
\beta=\pm \pi, \text { i.e., } \theta=\pm \sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{\lambda}{a}\right)
$$The first interference minimum occurs at

$$
3 \gamma=\pm \frac{\pi}{2} \text {, i.e., } \theta=\pm \sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{\lambda}{6 d}\right) \text {. }
$$

Problem Statement:
A partially elliptically polarized beam of light, propagating in the $z$ diroction, passes through a perfect linear polarization analyser. When the tranemission axis of the analyzer is along the $x$ direction, the transmitted intensity is maximum and has the value $1.5 I_{0}$. When the transmission axis is along the $y$ direction, the transmitted intensity is minimum and has the value $I_{0}$.

The original beam is made to pass first through a quarter-wave plate and then through the linear polarization analyzer. The quarter-wave plate has its axes lined up with the $x$ and $y$ ares. It is now found that the maximum intensity is transmitted through the two devices when the analyzer transmission axis makes an angle of $30^{\circ}$ with the $x$-axis.

Determine what this maximum intensity is.
Solution:
Let the intensity of the unpolarized light after passing through the analyzer be $I_{u}$. This will remain constant whatever angle the transmission axis makes with the $x$-axis. Let the intensities of the $x$ and $y$ components of the elliptically polarized light be $I_{e x}$ and $I_{e y}$ respectively. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{x}=1.5 I_{0}=I_{u}+I_{\mathrm{ex}}, \\
&I_{y}=1.0 I_{0}=I_{u}+I_{\mathrm{ey}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Fig. $2.69$

An elliptical vibration can be considered as made up of two mutually perpendicular linear ones $90^{\circ}$ out of phase as shown in Fig. 2.69. Its electric field vector can be represented by

$$
\mathbf{E}_{\theta}=\mathbf{E}_{x} \cos \theta+\mathbf{E}_{y} \sin \theta .
$$

The intensity of the polarized component $I_{e}$ is then $I_{e} \sim\left|\mathbb{E}_{0}\right|^{2}$, or

$$
I_{e}=I_{e x} \cos ^{2} \theta+I_{e y} \sin ^{2} \theta .
$$

Hence, writing $I_{u}=I_{u} \cos ^{2} \theta+I_{u} \sin ^{2} \theta$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
I(\theta) &=I_{\mathrm{e}}+I_{\mathrm{u}}=\left(I_{\mathrm{ex}}+I_{\mathrm{u}}\right) \cos ^{2} \theta+\left(I_{\mathrm{ey}}+I_{\mathrm{u}}\right) \sin ^{2} \theta \\
&=1.5 I_{0} \cos ^{2} \theta+I_{0} \sin ^{2} \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus $I(\theta)$ does not depend on what fraction of the light is unpolarised.A $\frac{\lambda}{4}$ plate introduces a $90^{\circ}$ phase change between the two mutually perpendicular components and makes the elliptically polarised light linear polarised. As

we have

$$
\frac{\sqrt{I_{e y}}}{\sqrt{I_{e x}}}=\tan 30^{\circ}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}
$$

$$
I_{e y}=\frac{I_{e x}}{3} .
$$

Combining it with the two original equations yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{\mathrm{ex}}=0.75 I_{0}, I_{\mathrm{ey}}=0.25 I_{0}, \\
&I_{\mathrm{u}}=0.75 I_{0} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the maximum intensity is

$$
I_{e x}+I_{e y}+I_{u}=1.75 I_{0}
$$

when $\theta=30^{\circ}$. The unpolarized fraction of the incident intensity is

$$
\frac{2 I_{u}}{1.5 I_{0}+I_{0}}=0.60 \text {. }
$$

Problem Statement:
A Young double-slit interferometer receives light from a stellar object which is focused at the plane shown in the figure.

If the interferometer is pointed at a stellar object subtending, at the earth, an angle greater than $\theta_{\min}$, the pattern disappears. Find $\theta_{\min}$.
Solution:
Let the width of each slit be $a$ and the angular sise of the star be $\theta$. To good approximation the intensity distribution of the interference pattern is given by the result of Question 2007:

$$
I(x, \theta) \sim\left(\frac{\sin \beta}{\beta}\right)^{2}\left(1+\frac{\sin \alpha}{\alpha} \cos \gamma\right)
$$

where

$$
\beta=\frac{\pi a x}{\lambda f}, \alpha=\frac{\pi d \theta}{\lambda}, \gamma=\frac{2 \pi d x}{\lambda f} .
$$The visibility of the pattern is given by

$$
V=\frac{I_{\max }-I_{\min }}{I_{\max }+I_{\min }},
$$

where $I_{\max }$ and $I_{\min }$ are the intensities at the neighboring maximum and minimum respectively. Thus

$$
V=\frac{\sin \alpha}{\alpha} .
$$

As $\theta$ increases from 0 to $\theta_{\min }, V$ decreases from 1 to 0 , where $\theta_{\min }$ is given by

$$
\frac{\pi d \theta_{\min }}{\lambda}=\pi \text {, or } \theta_{\min }=\frac{\lambda}{d} .
$$

The pattern also appears when $\theta \geq \theta_{\min }$. Actually, beyond $\theta_{\min }$ the pattern may reappear and then disappear again many times but the fluctuation of $V$ around 0 becomes smaller and smaller.

Problem Statement: A plane wave of light from a laser has a wavelength of $6000 \AA$. The light is incident on a double slit. After passing through the double slit the light falls on a screen $100 \mathrm{~cm}$ beyond the double slit. The intensity distribution of the interference pattern on the screen is shown in the figure. What is the width of each slit?
Solution:
For double-slit interference

$$
I \sim\left(\frac{\sin \beta}{\beta}\right)^{2} \cos ^{2} \gamma
$$

where

$$
\beta=\frac{\pi b \sin \theta}{\lambda}, \gamma=\frac{\pi d \sin \theta}{\lambda} \text {, with } \sin \theta \approx \frac{y}{D},
$$

$b$ being the width of each slit, $d$ the separation of their centers, $D$ the distance between the screen and the double slit, and $\lambda$ the wavelength of the incident light. The minima are given by $\gamma=\left(n+\frac{1}{2}\right) \pi, n=\pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots$. Thus the fringe spacing $\Delta y$ is given by

$$
\Delta y=\frac{\Delta y}{\pi} \frac{\lambda D}{d}=\frac{\lambda D}{d} .
$$

Hence, for $\Delta y=1 \mathrm{~cm}$ as from Fig. 2.48,

$$
d=\lambda D / \Delta y=6 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~cm} .
$$

The pattern shows the missing order $d / b=4$, from which we get the width of each slit, $b=d / 4=1.5 \times 10^{-9} \mathrm{~cm}$.

Problem Statement:
A plane light wave of wavelength $\lambda$ is incident normally on a grating consisting of 6 identical parallel slits a distance $d$ apart.

What is the angular width of the interference maxima, say from the maximum to the nearest null?
Solution:
The intensity distribution for Fraunhofer diffraction is given by

$$
I=I_{0} \frac{\sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi w \sin \theta}{\lambda}\right)}{\left(\frac{\pi w \sin \theta}{\lambda}\right)^{2}} \frac{\sin ^{2}\left(\frac{N \pi d \sin \theta}{\lambda}\right)}{\sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi d \sin \theta}{\lambda}\right)},
$$

where $N$ is the number of slits (in this case $N=6$ ), $w$ the width of a slit, $d$ the grating constant, $I_{0}$ the intensity in the $\theta=0$ direction due to any one slit.

The interference maxima occur when $\frac{\pi d \sin \theta}{\lambda}=k \pi,(k=0, \pm 1, \pm 2, \ldots)$, i.e., $\sin \theta=\frac{k \lambda}{d}$.

Minima, of zero intensity, occur when

$$
\frac{N \pi d \sin \theta}{\lambda}=m \pi,(m=\text { integer } \neq 0, \pm N, \pm 2 N, \ldots),
$$

i.e.,

$$
\frac{\pi d \sin \theta}{\lambda}=\pm \pi / N, \pm 2 \pi / N, \ldots,(N-1) \pi / N,(N+1) \pi / N, \ldots .
$$

Hence, the angular width of the interference maxima is $\Delta \theta \approx \lambda /(N d)$.

Problem Statement:

Problem Statement: In a compound microscope the focal length of the objective is $0.5 \mathrm{~cm}$ and that of the eyepiece is $2 \mathrm{~cm}$. If the distance between lenses is $22 \mathrm{~cm}$, what should the distance from the object to the objective be if the observer focuses for image at $\infty$?
Solution:
Apply the lens equation $\frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{q}=\frac{1}{f}$. For the eyepiece (subscript 2), $q_{2}=\infty$, we get $p_{2}=f_{2}=2 \mathrm{~cm}$.

For the objective (subscript 1),

$$
q_{1}=d-p_{2}=20 \mathrm{~cm},
$$

where $d$ is the distance between the lenses. With $f_{1}=0.5 \mathrm{~cm}$, we get $p_{1}=0.51 \mathrm{~cm}$. Hence, the object is located $0.51 \mathrm{~cm}$ in front of the objective.

To find the magnifying power, let the object length be $y$. The length of the image formed by the objective is

$$
y^{\prime}=\frac{q_{1}}{p_{1}} y .
$$

The angle subtended at the eye by the final image is then

$$
\alpha^{\prime}=\frac{y^{\prime}}{f_{2}}=\frac{q_{1}}{p_{1}} \frac{y}{f_{2}} .
$$

The angle subtended at the eye by the object without use of microscope is

$$
\alpha=\frac{y}{15} .
$$

Hence the magnifying power of the microscope is

$$
m=\frac{\alpha^{\prime}}{\alpha}=\frac{15 q_{1}}{p_{1} f_{2}}=2.9 \times 10^{2} .
$$

Problem Statement: Given two identical watch glasses glued together, the rear one silvered. Using autocollimation as sketched in the figure, sharp focus is obtained for $L=20 \mathrm{~cm}$. Find $L$ for sharp focus when the space between the glasses is subsequently filled with water, $n=\frac{4}{3}$.
Solution:
With air between the glasses, only the silvered watch glass reflects and converges the rays to form an image, i.e., the system acts as a concave mirror. The formula for a concave mirror

$$
\frac{1}{u}+\frac{1}{v}=\frac{2}{r}
$$

gives for $u=v=20 \mathrm{~cm}, r=20 \mathrm{~cm}$.

With water between the glasses, the incident light is refracted twice at $A$ and reflected once at $B$ before forming the final image. Note that the first image formed by $A$ falls behind the mirror $B$ and becomes a virtual object to $B$. Similarly the image formed by $B$ is a virtual object to $A$. We therefore have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{L}+\frac{n}{x} &=\frac{n-1}{20}, \\
-\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{y} &=\frac{1}{10}, \\
-\frac{n}{y}+\frac{1}{L} &=\frac{n-1}{20},
\end{aligned}
$$

which yield $L=12 \mathrm{~cm}$.

Thus, a sharp image will be formed at $L=12 \mathrm{~cm}$.

Problem Statement: A glass rod of rectangular cross-section is bent into the shape shown in the figure. A parallel beam of light falls perpendicularly on the flat surface $A$. We have to consider the conditions under which the ray will undergo total internal reflection before reaching $B$.

If $\alpha>\theta_{c}$, the critical angle, at which total internal reflection occurs, all the incident beam will emerge through the surface B. Hence we require

$$
\sin \alpha>\frac{1}{n} .
$$

The geometry gives

$$

or

$$
\left(\frac{R}{d}\right)_{\min }=\frac{1}{n-1}=\frac{1}{1.5-1}=2 .
$$

Problem Statement:
Suppose right-handed circularly polarised light (defined to be clockwise as the observer looks toward the oncoming wave) is incident on an absorbing slab. The slab is suspended by a vertical thread. The light is directed upwards and hits the underside of the slab.

If the circularly polarised light is 1 watt of wavelength $6200 \AA$, and if all of this light is absorbed by the slab, what is the torque, $\tau_{0}$, exerted on the slab in dyne-cm?
Solution:
If a beam of circularly polarized light is completely absorbed by an object on which it falls, an angular momentum

$$
\tau_{0}=W / \omega
$$

is transferred to the object so that a torque is exerted on the object, where $W$ is the amount of energy absorbed per second and $\omega$ is the angular frequency of the light. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tau_{0} &=W / \omega=\frac{W \lambda}{2 \pi c}=\frac{1 \times 0.62 \times 10^{-6}}{2 \pi \times 3 \times 10^{8}}=3.3 \times 10^{-16} \mathrm{~N} . \mathrm{m} \\
&=3.3 \times 10^{-9} \text { dyn. } \mathrm{cm} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement:
A plane wave of wavelength $\lambda$ is incident on a system having 3 slits of width a separated by distances $d$. The middle slit is covered by a filter which introduces a $180^{\circ}$ phase change.

Calculate the angle $\theta$ for the first diffraction minimum.
Solution:
By the Huygens-Fresnel principle, the amplitude at a point on the screen is given by (for Fraunhofer diffraction)

$$
\begin{aligned}
\psi=& \frac{A_{0}}{a} e^{-i w t}\left[\int_{0}^{a} e^{i 2 \rho x} d x\right.\\
&\left.+\int_{d}^{d+a} e^{i(2 \rho x+\pi)} d x+\int_{2 d}^{2 d+a} e^{i 2 \rho x} d x\right] \\
=& A_{0} e^{-i w t} e^{i \rho a} \frac{\sin (\rho a)}{\rho a}\left(1-e^{i 2 \rho d}+e^{i 4 \rho d}\right) e^{i 2 \rho d} \\
=& A_{0} e^{i(\beta+4 \gamma-w t)} \frac{\sin \beta}{\beta} \frac{\cos (3 \gamma)}{\cos \gamma},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\rho=\frac{\pi}{\lambda} \sin \theta, \beta=\rho a, \gamma=\rho d$. Thus

$$
I \sim\left(\frac{\sin \beta}{\beta}\right)^{2}\left[\frac{\cos (3 \gamma)}{\cos \gamma}\right]^{2} .
$$

The first diffraction minimum occurs at

$$
\beta=\pm \pi, \text { i.e., } \theta=\pm \sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{\lambda}{a}\right)
$$

x^{\prime}=-22.5 \mathrm{~cm} \text {. }

The negative sign indicates that the image is to the left of $F^{\prime}$. The magnification is $m=\frac{-1}{x}=1.5$. Then the image is upright, virtual and magnified $1.5$ times.

Problem Statement:
A new and important experimental technique being used in several sub-fields of physics is the use of ultra-short light pulses for studying fast phenomena. The ultra-short pulses are produced by mode-locking a laser - a method to be studied in this problem. The model laser consists of an optical cavity of length $L$ with transverse dimensions $d$ formed by two flat mirrors as shown in the first figure.

The amplifying medium (it may be solid, liquid, or gas) can be characterized by a certain gain spectrum (see the second figure); only light within this band of frequencies will be amplified. To simplify calculation, assume the gain spectrum is rectangular as shown in the third figure.

To be specific, consider the amplifying medium Nd glass, which has $\omega_{0}=1.8 \times 10^{15} \mathrm{sec}^{-1}, \Delta \omega=6 \times 10^{12} \mathrm{sec}^{-1}$, and take the length of the laser to be $L=150 \mathrm{~cm}$.

By inserting a modulated absorber into the cavity, one can lock the phases of all the modes to the same value, so that traveling waves interfere constructively, producing light pulses. Find the intensity as a function of time in this phase-locked or mode-locked case. What is the pulse duration? Consider only one polarisation.
Solution:
The longitudinal modes that can exist in a cavity of length $L$ are those for which

$$
L=n \frac{\lambda}{2}, \quad(n=1,2,3, \ldots),
$$

i.e.,

$$
\omega_{L}=\frac{2 \pi c}{\lambda}=\frac{\pi n c}{L} .
$$

Hence the separation between adjacent modes is

$$
\delta \omega_{L}=\frac{\pi c}{L}=6.3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~s}^{-1} .
$$If the relative phases $\phi_{n}$ of the different modes are randomly distributed, the modes are incoherent with one another, and the total intensity is the sum of the intensities of the individual modes; that is

$$
I=\text { integer }\left(\frac{\Delta \omega}{\delta \omega_{L}}\right) \cdot I_{0}=9549 I_{0} .
$$With mode-locking, the intensity must now be found by first adding up the electric fields, rather than the intensities directly,

where

$$
I(t)=I_{0}\left|e^{-i \omega_{1} t}+\ldots+e^{-i \omega_{n} t}\right|^{2}=I_{0}\left[\frac{\sin \frac{n \delta \omega_{L} t}{2}}{\sin \frac{\delta \omega_{L} t}{2}}\right]^{2}
$$

The pulse duration is

$$
\omega_{n}=n \delta \omega_{L}, n=\text { integer }\left(\frac{\Delta \omega}{\delta \omega_{L}}\right)=9549 .
$$

$$
\Delta t=\frac{2 \pi}{n \delta \omega_{L}}=\frac{2 L}{n c}=1.05 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{~s} .
$$

The pulse separation is the interval between two maxima:

$$
\Delta_{t}=\frac{2 \pi}{\delta \omega_{L}}=10^{-8} \mathrm{~s} .
$$

The peak intensity occurs at $t=0$ :

$$
I(0)=I_{0} \cdot n^{2}=9.12 \times 10^{7} I_{0} .
$$

Problem Statement: A double-slit interference is produced by plane parallel light of wavelength $\lambda$ passing through two slits of unequal widths, say $w_{1}=20 \lambda$ and $w_{\Omega}=40 \lambda$, their centers being $1000 \lambda$ apart. If the observation is made on a screen very far away from the slits, i.e., at a distance $L \gg 1000 \lambda$, determine the intensity ratio between intensity maximum and minimum in the center of the pattern.

As $w_{2}=2 w_{1}, L>w_{1}, w_{2}$, we may take the amplitudes of the electric field vectors produced by the slits $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ individually on the screen to be $E$ and $2 E$ respectively. For double-slit interference the resultant amplitude is given by the vector sum of $E_{1}$ and $E_{2}$ making an angle $\delta$ equal to the phase difference. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=I_{1}+I_{2}+2 \sqrt{I_{1} I_{2}} \cos \delta \\
&=I_{0}+4 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2 \pi d \sin \theta / \lambda)=5 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2000 \pi \sin \theta),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $d$ is the separation of the centres of the slits, being equal to $1000 \lambda$, $\sin \theta \approx \frac{x}{L}, x$ being the distance on the screen from the centre of the interference pattern. As $L>x, \sin \theta \simeq \theta$ and adjacent maxima occur when $2000 \pi \delta \theta=2 \pi$, or $\delta \theta=\frac{1}{1000}$, giving

$$
\delta x=L \delta \theta=\frac{L}{1000} .
$$The diffraction intensity distribution due to a slit of width $w$ is given by $\sim\left(\frac{\sin \beta}{\beta}\right)^{2}$, where $\beta=\frac{\pi w}{\lambda} \sin \theta$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{1}=I_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{1} / \beta_{1}\right)^{2}, \quad \text { where } \beta_{1}=\pi w_{1} \sin \theta / \lambda=20 \pi \sin \theta, \\
&I_{2}=4 I_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{2} / \beta_{2}\right)^{2}, \quad \text { where } \beta_{2}=\pi w_{2} \sin \theta / \lambda=40 \pi \sin \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

The first zeros occur at angular distances from the centre of $\theta_{1}$ and $\theta_{2}$ given by

$$
20 \pi \sin \theta_{1} \simeq 20 \pi \theta_{1}=\pi \text {, or } \theta_{1}=\frac{1}{20} \text {, and } \theta_{2}=\frac{1}{40} \text {. }
$$

Hence the angular widths of the central maxima are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \theta_{1}=2 \theta_{1} &=\frac{1}{10}, \\
\Delta \theta_{2} &=\frac{1}{20} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The corresponding widths are then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\Delta x_{1}=L \theta_{1}=L / 10, \\
&\Delta x_{2}=L \theta_{2}=L / 20 .
\end{aligned}
$$The width of the overlap of these central maxima is $L / 20$, and the number of fringes is $(\mathrm{L} / 20) /(\mathrm{L} / 1000)=50$.The intensity maximum and minimum in the center of the pattern are given by $\cos \delta=1$ and $\cos \delta=-1$ respectively. Hence we have the ratio

$$
\frac{I_{\max }}{I_{\min }}=\frac{9 I_{0}}{I_{0}}=9 .
$$

Problem Statement:
Monochromatic parallel light impinges normally on an opaque screen with a circular hole of radius $r$ and is detected on the axis a distance $L$ from the hole. The intensity is observed to oscillate as $r$ is increased from 0 to $\infty$.

Find the radius $r_{b}$ of the hole for the first minimum.
Solution:
For parallel incident light and a point on the axis distance $L$ from the hole, the radii of the Fresnel zones are given by

$$
r_{k}=\sqrt{k \lambda L}, \quad(k=1,2,3, \ldots) .
$$

For the first maximum, $k=1, r_{\mathrm{a}}=r_{1}=\sqrt{\lambda L}$.For the first minimum, $k=2, r_{b}=r_{2}=\sqrt{2 \lambda L}$.

Problem Statement: A soap film $(n=4 / 3)$ of thickness $d$ is illuminated at normal incidence by light of wavelength $500 \mathrm{~nm}$. Calculate the approximate intensity of interference maxima in terms of the incident intensity $I_0$ as $d$ is varied, when viewed in reflected light.
Solution:
The reflectivity at each surface of the soap film is given by

$$
R=\left[\frac{\left(n-n_{0}\right)}{\left(n+n_{0}\right)}\right]^{2}=\left[\frac{\left(\frac{4}{3}-1\right)}{\left(\frac{4}{3}+1\right)}\right]^{2} \approx 0.02 .
$$

For a film of low reflectivity $R$, the intensity of the reflected light at either surface can be approximately represented by $R I_{0}$, where $I_{0}$ is the intensity of the incident light. The intensity of the interference pattern is therefore

$$
I=2 R I_{0}(1+\cos \delta)_{1}
$$

where $\sigma$ is the phase difference between the beams of reflected light at the two surfaces of the soap film given by

$$
\delta=\left(\frac{2 \pi d}{\lambda}\right) \cos \theta,
$$

$\theta$ being the angle of incidence. 

Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I \max / I_{0}=4 R=0.08 \\
&I_{\min } / I_{0}=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement:
Sunlight is normally incident on the surface of water with index of refraction $n=1.33$.

If the incident flux is $1 \mathrm{~kW} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$, what is the pressure that sunlight exerts on the surface of the water?
Solution:
Fresnel's formulae give for normally incidence

$$
\begin{aligned}
&R=\left(\frac{n_{2}-n_{1}}{n_{2}+n_{1}}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{n-1}{n+1}\right)^{2}=0.02 \\
&T=\frac{4 n_{1} n_{2}}{\left(n_{2}+n_{1}\right)^{2}}=\frac{4 n}{(n+1)^{2}}=0.98 \\
&R+T=1
\end{aligned}
$$

From the point of view of the photon theory, light pressure is the result of a transfer of the momentum of the incoming light to the target. If $W$ is the incident flux density and $R$ the reflection coefficient, the change of momentum per unit area is

$$
\frac{W R}{c}-\left(-\frac{W}{c}\right)=\frac{(1+R) W}{c} .
$$

By definition this is the light pressure $p$

$$
p=\frac{(1+0.02) \times 1000}{3 \times 10^{8}}=3.34 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2} .
$$

Problem Statement: A double-slit interference is produced by plane parallel light of wavelength $\lambda$ passing through two slits of unequal widths, say $w_{1}=20 \lambda$ and $w_{\Omega}=40 \lambda$, their centers being $1000 \lambda$ apart. If the observation is made on a screen very far away from the slits, i.e., at a distance $L \gg 1000 \lambda$, determine the width $\Delta x_{1}$ of the central maximum of the diffraction pattern of the first slit (i.e., distance between the first zeros).
Solution:
As $w_{2}=2 w_{1}, L>w_{1}, w_{2}$, we may take the amplitudes of the electric field vectors produced by the slits $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ individually on the screen to be $E$ and $2 E$ respectively. Since $I \propto E^{2}$, the corresponding intensities are $I_{1}=I_{0}$, say, $I_{2}=4 I_{0}$. For double-slit interference the resultant amplitude is given by the vector sum of $E_{1}$ and $E_{2}$ making an angle $\delta$ equal to the phase difference. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=I_{1}+I_{2}+2 \sqrt{I_{1} I_{2}} \cos \delta \\
&=I_{0}+4 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2 \pi d \sin \theta / \lambda)=5 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2000 \pi \sin \theta),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $d$ is the separation of the centres of the slits, being equal to $1000 \lambda$, $\sin \theta \approx \frac{x}{L}, x$ being the distance on the screen from the centre of the interference pattern. As $L>x, \sin \theta \simeq \theta$ and adjacent maxima occur when $2000 \pi \delta \theta=2 \pi$, or $\delta \theta=\frac{1}{1000}$, giving

$$
\delta x=L \delta \theta=\frac{L}{1000} .
$$The diffraction intensity distribution due to a slit of width $w$ is given by $\sim\left(\frac{\sin \beta}{\beta}\right)^{2}$, where $\beta=\frac{\pi w}{\lambda} \sin \theta$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{1}=I_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{1} / \beta_{1}\right)^{2}, \quad \text { where } \beta_{1}=\pi w_{1} \sin \theta / \lambda=20 \pi \sin \theta, \\
&I_{2}=4 I_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{2} / \beta_{2}\right)^{2}, \quad \text { where } \beta_{2}=\pi w_{2} \sin \theta / \lambda=40 \pi \sin \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

The first zeros occur at angular distances from the centre of $\theta_{1}$ and $\theta_{2}$ given by

$$
20 \pi \sin \theta_{1} \simeq 20 \pi \theta_{1}=\pi \text {, or } \theta_{1}=\frac{1}{20} \text {, and } \theta_{2}=\frac{1}{40} \text {. }
$$

Hence the angular widths of the central maxima are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \theta_{1}=2 \theta_{1} &=\frac{1}{10}, \\
\Delta \theta_{2} &=\frac{1}{20} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The corresponding widths are then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\Delta x_{1}=L \theta_{1}=L / 10, \\
&\Delta x_{2}=L \theta_{2}=L / 20 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement:
A point source, $Q$, emits coherent light isotropically at two frequencies, $\omega$ and $\omega+\Delta \omega$, with equal power, $I$ joules/sec, at each frequency. Two detectors, $A$ and $B$, each with a (small) sensitive area $S$ capable of responding to individual photons, are located at distances $l_{A}$ and $l_{B}$ from $Q$ as shown in the figure. In the following, take $\frac{\Delta \omega}{\omega} \ll 1$ and assume the experiment is carried out in vacuum.

Calculate the photon counting rate (photons/sec) at $A$ as a function of time. Consider time scales $>1 / \omega$.
Solution:
The waves of angular frequencies $\omega_{1}$ and $\omega_{2}$ arriving at $A$ can be represented by

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{1} &=\frac{E_{0}}{l_{A}} e^{i\left(\omega_{1} t-k_{2} l_{A}\right)} \\
E_{2} &=\frac{E_{0}}{l_{A}} e^{i\left(\omega_{2} t-k_{2} l_{A}\right)}
\end{aligned}
$$

respectively, where $\omega_{1}=\omega, \omega_{2}=\omega+\Delta \omega$. The resultant wave at $A$ is then

$$
E_{\mathrm{A}}=E_{1}+E_{2}=\left(E_{0} / l_{\mathrm{A}}\right)\left[e^{i\left(\omega_{1} t-k_{1} l_{\mathrm{A}}\right)}+e^{i\left(\omega_{2} t-k_{2} l_{A}\right)}\right]
$$

and the intensity at $A$, time-averaged, is

$$
I_{\mathrm{A}} \sim \frac{1}{2} E_{\mathrm{A}} E_{\mathrm{A}}^{*}=\left(\frac{E_{0}}{l_{\mathrm{A}}}\right)^{2}\left\{1+\cos \left[\left(\omega_{2}-\omega_{1}\right) t-\left(k_{2}-k_{1}\right) l_{\mathrm{A}}\right]\right\} .
$$

The constant phase difference $\left(k_{2}-k_{1}\right) l_{A}$ can be taken as zero by choosing a suitable time origin. The intensity of the $\omega_{1}$ wave at $A$ is

As the source has power $I$ and is isotropic,

$$
I_{1} \sim \frac{1}{2} E_{1} E_{1}^{*}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{E_{0}}{l_{\mathrm{A}}}\right)^{2} .
$$

giving

$$
I_{1}=\frac{I}{4 \pi l_{A}^{2}},
$$

Hence

$$
\left(\frac{E_{0}}{l_{A}}\right)^{2} \sim \frac{I}{2 \pi l_{A}^{2}} .
$$

The photon counting rate at $A$ is

$$
I_{A}=\frac{I}{2 \pi l_{A}^{2}}[1+\cos (\Delta \omega t)] .
$$

Similarly, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{\mathrm{A}}(t) &=\frac{I_{\mathrm{A}}(t) S}{\hbar \omega} . \\
&=\frac{I S}{2 \pi \hbar \omega l_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}}[1+\cos (\Delta \omega t)] .
\end{aligned}
$$

As

$$
I_{\mathrm{B}}(t)=\frac{I}{2 \pi l_{\mathrm{B}}^{2}}\left\{1+\cos \left[\Delta \omega t+\left(l_{\mathrm{B}}-l_{\mathrm{A}}\right)\left(k_{1}-k_{2}\right) \mid\right\} .\right.
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
&k_{1}=\frac{\omega_{1}}{c}=\frac{\omega}{c}, \\
&k_{2}=\frac{\omega_{2}}{c}=\frac{\omega+\Delta \omega}{c}, \\
&k_{1}-k_{2}=-\frac{\Delta \omega}{c},
\end{aligned}
$$

we have

$$
I_{B}(t)=\frac{I}{2 \pi l_{B}^{2}}\left\{1+\cos \left[\Delta \omega t+\frac{\left(l_{A}-l_{B}\right)}{c} \Delta \omega\right]\right\},
$$

giving

$$
R_{\mathrm{B}}(t)=\frac{I S}{2 \pi \hbar \omega l_{\mathrm{A}}^{2}}\left\{1+\cos \left[\Delta \omega t+\frac{\left(l_{\mathrm{A}}-l_{\mathrm{B}}\right) \Delta \omega}{c}\right]\right\} .
$$

Problem Statement:
A beam of light, with $\lambda=5000 \AA$, traveling in the $z$-direction is polarised at $45^{\circ}$ to the $x$-direction. It passes through a Kerr cell, i.e., a substance such that $n_{x}-n_{y}=K E^{2}$, where $n_{x}$ and $n_{y}$ are the refractive indices for light polarised in the $x$ and $y$ directions. $E$ is the strength of an externally applied electric field in the $x$-direction. The cell has length $1 \mathrm{~cm}$ and $K=2.5 \times 10^{-6} \text{(meter)}^{2} /\text{(volts)}^{2}$.

If the light, after passing through the Kerr cell, passes through a polarization analyzer whose plane of polarisation is perpendicular to that of the original beam, calculate the smallest value of $E$ which gives maximum transmission. Assume the effect of the electric field on reflection at the Kerr cell is negligible.
Solution:
The Kerr cell induces birefringence. As the direction of the electric field is $45^{\circ}$ to the direction of polarisation of the light, the amplitudes of the components polarised parallel to the $x$ and $y$ directions are the same. When the phase difference $\delta$ between the components is

$$
\delta=\frac{2 \pi l\left(n_{x}-n_{y}\right)}{\lambda}=\frac{2 \pi l K E^{2}}{\lambda}=(2 j+1) \pi, j=0 \text { or integer, }
$$

the Kerr cell acts as a half-wave plate and rotates the plane of polarization by $90^{\circ} s 0$ that it coincides with the transmission axis of the analyzer and gives maximum transmission. Putting $j=0$ yields the smallest $E, E_{\min }$, which is given by

$$
E_{\min }^{2}=\frac{\lambda}{2 K l}=10 \quad \mathrm{~V}^{2} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \text { for } l=1 \mathrm{~cm} .
$$
